description: National Electrical Code requirements for elevators, escalators, and moving walks

questions.question: What NEC article covers electrical requirements for elevators?
questions.explanation: NEC Article 620 covers the electrical installation of elevators, dumbwaiters, escalators, moving walks, platform lifts, and stairway chairlifts.

questions.question: What is the minimum size for elevator traveling cables?
questions.explanation: Traveling cables must be rated at least 20 AWG for operating control and signal circuits. Power conductors have separate requirements based on load.

questions.question: What type of disconnecting means is required for each elevator?
options: Enclosed externally operated fused switch or circuit breaker
questions.explanation: Each elevator must have a disconnecting means that is an enclosed externally operable fused switch or circuit breaker lockable in the open position.

questions.question: Where must the main line disconnecting means for an elevator be located?
options: In the main electrical room only
In the machine room or control room
questions.explanation: The disconnecting means must be located in the machine room or control room where it is readily accessible to qualified persons.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the shunt trip on an elevator disconnecting means?
options: To disconnect power during fire conditions
questions.explanation: Shunt trip disconnects (where required) automatically disconnect elevator power when fire alarm or sprinkler systems activate, per NEC and fire code requirements.

questions.question: What lighting is required in an elevator machine room?
questions.explanation: At least one permanently installed lighting outlet must be provided in elevator machine rooms, with the switch located at the point of entry.

questions.question: What is required for elevator pit lighting?
options: At least one 125V 20A receptacle and lighting outlet
questions.explanation: Elevator pits must have at least one 125V, 15A or 20A receptacle and a permanently installed lighting outlet with switch accessible from the pit access door.

questions.question: Where must the elevator car lighting operating switch be located?
options: In the car or accessible from outside
questions.explanation: The car light switch must be accessible to persons in the car or from outside the car for maintenance access.

questions.question: What percentage of elevator feeder demand factor may be applied when there are multiple elevators?
questions.explanation: NEC 620.14 provides a demand factor table based on the number of elevators. The percentage decreases as the number of elevators increases.

questions.question: What is the ampacity requirement for elevator feeder conductors?
options: Based on specific calculation method in Article 620
questions.explanation: Feeder ampacity must be calculated per NEC 620.13, which considers motor full-load current, demand factors, and other connected loads.

questions.question: What wiring method is required in the hoistway?
options: Rigid metal conduit or MI cable only
Wiring methods suitable for the environment
questions.explanation: Wiring in hoistways must use wiring methods suitable for the environment and conditions. Hard-service cord is permitted for traveling cables.

questions.question: What is the minimum clear working space required at elevator controllers?
questions.explanation: Working space at elevator controllers must comply with NEC 110.26 requirements for electrical equipment, typically 36 inches clear in front.

questions.question: When is selective coordination required for elevator circuits?
options: When required by building code or AHJ
questions.explanation: Selective coordination of elevator circuit protective devices may be required by the building code or authority having jurisdiction for critical operations.

questions.question: What type of emergency power system is required for elevators in high-rise buildings?
questions.explanation: Emergency power for elevators is typically required by building codes (IBC) rather than NEC. NEC addresses wiring but not the requirement for emergency power.

questions.question: What is required for elevator motor branch circuit short-circuit protection?
options: Up to 200% of motor FLC for fuses
Special rules allowing higher protection values
questions.explanation: NEC 620.62 allows elevator motor branch circuit protection up to 200% for fuses and 300% for breakers due to high inrush currents during motor starting.

questions.question: How must elevator car traveling cables be supported?
options: Must be supported to prevent strain on terminations
questions.explanation: Traveling cables must be supported at the car and machine room ends to prevent mechanical strain on the conductors and terminations.

questions.question: What voltage limitation applies to elevator control circuits?
options: 300V maximum for operating circuits in cars
questions.explanation: Operating control and signal circuits in elevator cars are limited to 300V or less for safety, with additional limitations in certain applications.

questions.question: What equipment grounding is required for elevator installations?
options: All metal raceways and equipment must be grounded
questions.explanation: All metal raceways, cable armor, and equipment enclosures must be bonded and grounded per NEC Part VII of Article 620.

questions.question: For regenerative drive elevators, how must regenerated power be handled?
options: Must be returned to the supply or absorbed by proper means
questions.explanation: Regenerative drives must have means to absorb or redirect regenerated power. This may include resistor banks or connection back to the supply system.

questions.question: What is required when elevator machine room contains more than one driving machine?
options: Each driving machine must have its own disconnect
questions.explanation: Where more than one driving machine is in a machine room, each driving machine must have an individual disconnecting means.

questions.question: What is the requirement for GFCI protection in elevator pits?
options: Only required if water is present
questions.explanation: All 125V, single-phase, 15A and 20A receptacles in elevator pits must have GFCI protection for personnel safety.

questions.question: What fire recall sequence applies to elevator power disconnection?
options: ASME A17.1 and fire codes specify sequence, NEC addresses wiring
questions.explanation: Fire recall sequencing is specified by ASME A17.1 and fire codes (NFPA 72). NEC provides wiring requirements for the shunt trip and other devices.

questions.question: What is the conductor ampacity calculation for an elevator motor rated 25 HP, 460V, 3-phase?
options: Use NEC Table 430.250 for motor FLC
questions.explanation: Motor FLC from NEC Table 430.250 is used (34A for 25HP, 460V). Then apply Article 620 specific calculations for feeder sizing.

questions.question: What is required when elevator controllers contain Class 2 circuits?
options: Must be separated from power wiring per Article 725
questions.explanation: Class 2 circuits must be separated from power-limited and non-power-limited circuits per NEC Article 725 requirements to prevent interference and safety issues.

questions.question: What overcurrent protection is permitted for elevator motor control transformer secondaries?
options: Secondary protection may be omitted per specific conditions
questions.explanation: NEC 620.62 permits omitting secondary overcurrent protection under specific conditions related to primary protection sizing and transformer impedance.
